Content-Type: text/plain; charset=windows-1252
Content-Transfer-Encoding: quoted-printable

Hi Ken,

Thanks.

We did actually try leveraging the species created by NEA=
T, but
unfortunately that wasn't useful for two reasons. First, the distrib=
ution
of the population was heavily lopsided. We had a population of 100 ge=
nomes
and 10 species, but the size of species 0 was usually around 80 genom=
es.
Second, even accounting for this, we saw better performance from random=
ly
selecting individuals for subcultures.

This makes intuitive sense to me=
, since speciation is intended for the
opposite of what subcultures should =
be doing. Speciation is aimed at
grouping similar individuals in genome spa=
ce, thereby protecting (with the
help of fitness sharing) innovation in the=
 population and allowing it to
flourish. Subcultures, however, are intended=
 to create diverse groups of
individuals in phenome space and thus promote =
the sharing of innovations
among the population. In this light, I think it'=
s clear why randomly
composed subcultures would outperform species-based: i=
ndividuals in the
same species, with similar genomes, are more likely to ha=
ve similar
phenotypic behavior and observations of similar individuals real=
ly won't
help social agents outside of some minor local optimization on the=

sub-policies they have already discovered.

Philosophically, I think the r=
esults are actually very encouraging when
applied to human society. We show=
 that the notion of learning only from
what those in power tell you is actu=
ally a suboptimal strategy. Rather,
everyone-- rich, poor, young, old, etc-=
- may have something to contribute
and even if overall they aren't as "fit"=
 as everyone else, their individual
actions can still have worth and add va=
lue to society.

Specifically to novelty, I believe social transmission is =
crucial in human
societies. Generally when biologists study learning paradi=
gms in nature,
there are a few levels of cognitive ability. In our experime=
nts we were
effectively applying  an emulation paradigm, where agents learn=
 to mimic
exact behaviors. Humans fortunately function at a higher level, i=
mitation,
because we can observe a behavior and then acquire new skills or =
talents by
combining it with other knowledge or experiences we've previousl=
y acquired,
resulting in an entirely new behavior. So from my perspective, =
social
learning among humans is one not a threat to novelty, but rather one=
 of the
greatest sources of it.

Sincerely,
Wesley

On Thu, Apr 19, 2012 at=
 6:48 PM, Ken <kstanley@...> wrote:

> **
>
>
>
>
> Hi Wesley, co=
ngrats on the GECCO paper and also thanks for sharing the
> software. I do =
have a couple questions/comments:
>
> The subculture idea is interesting bu=
t did you consider aligning the
> subcultures with the NEAT-determined spec=
ies divisions? It seems strange
> that a "subculture" could cut across spec=
ies, though I suppose the
> existence of dogs and cats in human households =
is sort of analogous. On the
> other hand when you can actually "learn" to =
be almost identical to another
> species (as you can when you are just a ne=
ural network) maybe it doesn't
> really matter that much what species you s=
tarted from.
>
> On a more philosophical level, it's interesting that teach=
ing in general
> is a kind of convergent force towards conformity. Obviousl=
y some of that is
> necessary in society, but it raises the question of whe=
ther societies
> transmit creativity through teaching (or at least can avoi=
d damaging
> creativity when teaching). This question is a bit abstract, bu=
t it does
> relate to novelty search - the kind of divergent proliferation =
of stepping
> stones seen in non-objective search is potentially inhibited =
in a social
> learning society. So it raises the question of whether you ca=
n actually
> have both social transmission and non-objective divergence tog=
ether.
> Interestingly, human society seems to have both ingredients workin=
g very
> effectively together.
>
> ken
>
>
> --- In neat@yahoogroups.com, W=
esley Tansey <tansey@...> wrote:
> >
> > Hi all,
> >
> > I'm proud to annou=
nce my first GECCO paper!
> >
> > Title: Accelerating Evolution via Egalita=
rian Social Learning
> > Authors: Wesley Tansey, Eliana Feasley, and Risto =
Miikkulainen
> >
> > Abstract:
> > Social learning is an extension to evolu=
tionary algorithms that enables
> > agents to learn from observations of ot=
hers in the population.
> > Historically, social learning algorithms have e=
mployed a student-teacher
> > model where the behavior of one or more high-=
fitness agents is used to
> > train a subset of the remaining agents in the=
 population. This paper
> > presents ESL, an egalitarian model of social le=
arning in which agents are
> > not labeled as teachers or students, instead=
 allowing any individual
> > receiving a sufficiently high reward to teach =
other agents to mimic its
> > recent behavior. We validate our approach thr=
ough a series of experiments
> > in a robot foraging domain, including comp=
arisons of egalitarian social
> > learning with baseline neuroevolution and=
 a variant of student-teacher
> > social learning. In a complex foraging ta=
sk, ESL converges to
> near-optimal
> > strategies faster than either bench=
mark approach, outperforming both by
> > more than an order of magnitude. T=
he results indicate that egalitarian
> > social learning is a promising new=
 paradigm for social learning in
> > intelligent agents.
> >
> > Paper page=
: http://nn.cs.utexas.edu/pub-view.php?PubID=3D127157
> >
> > Github reposi=
tory for all source code:
> > https://github.com/tansey/social-learning
> >=

> > A couple of things to note here that I believe will be very helpful to=

> > anyone using SharpNEAT in general:
> >
> > - If you're looking to do L=
amarckian evolution, it turns out to be very
> > easy: https://gist.github.=
com/2410490
> >
> > - We implemented backpropagation through time for the F=
astCyclicNetwork.
> > Using the SharpNeatV2 that is in the github repo, you=
 can perform
> > supervised learning on a NEAT network very easily, enablin=
g online
> learning
> > algorithms to be incorporated into SharpNEAT experi=
ments:
> > https://gist.github.com/2410545
> >
> > Colin, I'd love if you c=
ould take a look at the backprop implementation
> and
> > potentially integ=
rate it into a future release of SharpNEAT. Outside of
> our
> > hacking of=
 the FastCyclicNetwork class, it only required changing
> > permissions on =
a few properties here and there.
> >
> > The caveats here are that the back=
prop implementation requires you reset
> > the network state at every activ=
ation to be correct. If you're doing
> > something where recurrent networks=
 that maintain state between calls are
> > required, then the performance o=
f this method is not guaranteed to work.
> >
> > If anyone has any comments=
 or questions on the paper, I'm happy to
> discuss
> > it!
> >
> > Sincerel=
y,
> > Wesley
> >
>
>  
>

Hi Ken,<div><br></div><div>Thanks.</div><div><br></div><div>We did actually=
 try leveraging the species created by NEAT, but unfortunately that wasn&#3=
9;t useful for two reasons. First, the distribution of the population was h=
eavily lopsided. We had a population of 100 genomes and 10 species, but the=
 size of species 0 was usually around 80 genomes. Second, even accounting f=
or this, we saw better performance from randomly selecting individuals for =
subcultures.</div>
<div><br></div><div>This makes intuitive sense to me, si=
nce speciation is intended for the opposite of what subcultures should be d=
oing. Speciation is aimed at grouping similar individuals in genome space, =
thereby protecting=A0(with the help of fitness sharing)=A0innovation in the=
 population and allowing it to flourish. Subcultures, however, are intended=
 to create diverse groups of individuals in phenome space and thus promote =
the sharing of innovations among the population. In this light, I think it&=
#39;s clear why randomly composed subcultures would outperform species-base=
d: individuals in the same species, with similar genomes, are more likely t=
o have similar phenotypic behavior and observations of similar individuals =
really won't help social agents outside of some minor local optimizatio=
n on the sub-policies they have already discovered.</div>
<div><br></div><d=
iv>Philosophically, I think the results are actually very encouraging when =
applied to human society. We show that the notion of learning only from wha=
t those in power tell you is actually a suboptimal strategy. Rather, everyo=
ne-- rich, poor, young, old, etc-- may have something to contribute and eve=
n if overall they aren't as "fit" as everyone else, their ind=
ividual actions can still have worth and add value to society.</div>
<div><=
br></div><div>Specifically to novelty, I believe social transmission is cru=
cial in human societies. Generally when biologists study learning paradigms=
 in nature, there are a few levels of cognitive ability. In our experiments=
 we were effectively applying =A0an emulation paradigm, where agents learn =
to mimic exact behaviors. Humans fortunately function at a higher level, im=
itation, because we can observe a behavior and then acquire new skills or t=
alents by combining it with other knowledge or experiences we've previo=
usly acquired, resulting in an entirely new behavior. So from my perspectiv=
e, social learning among humans is one not a threat to novelty, but rather =
one of the greatest sources of it.</div>
<div><br></div><div>Sincerely,<br>=
Wesley</div><div><br><div class=3D"gmail_quote">On Thu, Apr 19, 2012 at 6:4=
8 PM, Ken <span dir=3D"ltr"><<a href=3D"mailto:kstanley@...">k=
stanley@...</a>></span> wrote:<br>
<blockquote class=3D"gmail_=
quote" style=3D"margin:0 0 0 .8ex;border-left:1px #ccc solid;padding-left:1=
ex">

<div>

   =
 <div>
      
      
      <p><br>
<br>
Hi Wesley, congrats on the GECCO pa=
per and also thanks for sharing the software.  I do have a couple questions=
/comments:  <br>
<br>
The subculture idea is interesting but did you consid=
er aligning the subcultures with the NEAT-determined species divisions?  It=
 seems strange that a "subculture" could cut across species, thou=
gh I suppose the existence of dogs and cats in human households is sort of =
analogous.  On the other hand when you can actually "learn" to be=
 almost identical to another species (as you can when you are just a neural=
 network) maybe it doesn't really matter that much what species you sta=
rted from.<br>

<br>
On a more philosophical level, it's interesting th=
at teaching in general is a kind of convergent force towards conformity.  O=
bviously some of that is necessary in society, but it raises the question o=
f whether societies transmit creativity through teaching (or at least can a=
void damaging creativity when teaching).  This question is a bit abstract, =
but it does relate to novelty search - the kind of divergent proliferation =
of stepping stones seen in non-objective search is potentially inhibited in=
 a social learning society.  So it raises the question of whether you can a=
ctually have both social transmission and non-objective divergence together=
.  Interestingly, human society seems to have both ingredients working very=
 effectively together.<br>

<br>
ken</p><div><div class=3D"h5"><br>
<br>
--=

r>

t-teacher<br>

aradigm for social learning in<br>
